name: Cognitive Therapy for PTSD
summary: A structured cognitive-behavioral approach that targets maladaptive trauma-related beliefs and appraisals to reduce post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms.
description: Cognitive Therapy for PTSD (CT-PTSD) is a trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral intervention designed to help individuals process and recover from post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Developed by Anke Ehlers and David Clark, CT-PTSD emphasizes identifying and modifying distorted appraisals of the trauma and its consequences, reducing unhelpful coping strategies (e.g., avoidance, rumination), and updating trauma memories to reduce distress. CT-PTSD is recommended as a first-line treatment for PTSD in multiple clinical guidelines and has strong empirical support.

clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe and well tolerated; temporary distress may occur when trauma memories are processed.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Strong—endorsed by NICE, APA, and international guidelines as a frontline PTSD treatment.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Multiple randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses confirm its efficacy in reducing PTSD and comorbid symptoms.

sections.text: CT-PTSD helps patients identify distorted trauma-related beliefs, update their understanding of the traumatic event, and reframe appraisals that maintain PTSD (e.g., guilt, shame, ongoing threat). Techniques include cognitive restructuring, imaginal reliving, and discrimination training to differentiate between past trauma cues and present safety.

sections.preparation: Comprehensive assessment of trauma history, PTSD symptoms, and coping strategies.
procedure: Psychoeducation about PTSD and its maintenance factors.
Identification of maladaptive appraisals of trauma.
Updating trauma memories through imaginal reliving and rescripting.

sections.pre_session: Symptom check-in and review of homework.
sections.treatment_phase: Cognitive restructuring, trauma memory work, behavioral experiments.
sections.post_session: Assign homework (practice reappraisals, exposure, behavioral activation).

common: Temporary increase in distress when discussing trauma
uncommon: Sleep disruption after imaginal reliving sessions
rare: Exacerbation of dissociation if not carefully managed

ideal_candidates: Individuals with PTSD ready for trauma-focused therapy
Patients motivated to examine and challenge trauma-related beliefs

practitioner: Licensed therapist trained in cognitive therapy for trauma

studies: Ehlers A, Clark DM. (2000). A cognitive model of PTSD: Research and treatment.
Ehlers A et al. (2005). Cognitive therapy for PTSD: Development and evaluation.
Lewis C et al. (2020). Systematic review and meta-analysis of trauma-focused CBT for PTSD.
sections.limitations: May require adaptation for complex trauma or high dissociation; not always effective without safety stabilization first.

sections.cost_effectiveness: Cost-effective given high recovery rates and reduced chronic PTSD care needs

sections.veterans: Evidence supports strong efficacy in combat-related PTSD.
sections.sexual-assault-survivors: Effective for trauma-related guilt and shame.
sections.adolescents: Adapted protocols are available for youth.

items: CT-PTSD is a first-line trauma-focused CBT intervention endorsed by NICE.
Strong research base for both individual trauma and multiple-event trauma.
Highly structured and time-limited, making it replicable and scalable.
